body:
### Problem

It is possible to crash Neovim by using a `TSNode` (or a query cursor) of a tree that was edited afterwards.

Details: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31631#discussion_r1898103653
TL;DR: 
1. Subtrees in tree-sitter are reference counted, but nodes and query cursors (which reference the subtree) do not contribute to the reference count.
2. Parsing might free the old subtree.
3. Some operation on nodes reference the subtree, and when it was freed, Neovim crashes.

This issue was submitted to tree-sitter, but closed: https://github.com/tree-sitter/tree-sitter/issues/4044#event-15776372680

### Steps to reproduce

minimal.lua:
```lua
local line = 'vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(0, { 1, 0 });'
local lines = {}
for i = 1, 2000 do lines[i] = line end

local lines2 = { 'local _ = "' .. line }
for i = 2, 1999 do lines2[i] = line end
table.insert(lines2, line .. '"')

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, lines)

vim.treesitter.start(0, 'lua')
local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(0)
parser:parse()

local trees = {}
for k, tree in pairs(parser:trees()) do
  trees[k] = tree:copy()
end

local nodes = {}
local function add_all(node)
  table.insert(nodes, node:child())
  for child in node:iter_children() do
    add_all(child)
  end
end
add_all(parser:parse(true)[1]:root())

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, lines2)
parser:parse(true)
trees = nil
collectgarbage("collect")

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, lines)
parser:parse()
collectgarbage("collect")

vim.keymap.set('n', 'a', function()
  for _, node in ipairs(nodes) do
    node:has_changes()
  end
  print('ended')
end)
```

```shell
nvim --clean -u minimal.lua
```

Pressing `a` will crash neovim

### Expected behavior

Neovim should not crash, or the docs should mention that it is possible to crash.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0-dev-1422+g35247b00a4

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

N/A

### Operating system/version

Ubuntu 24.04

### Terminal name/version

XTerm(390)

### $TERM environment variable

xterm

### Installation

build from repo

comment_data.body:
Possible solutions:

1. Copy the tree before creating new Lua wrappers for nodes and query cursors (and store the copy internally). Nodes and cursors will use that tree. On GC, release the associated tree.

Editing other trees will not affect the nodes that were created before. They will continue to work and return valid data, although from the old tree.

Copying a tree doesn't seem to be that expensive (atomic increment for subtree + copying the included ranges). 
Tree edits might get more expensive since when reference count is 1, the tree is modified in-place, and the nodes we allocated from that tree might not get garbage collected right away and still hold references to it.

2. Have our own reference count and changetick for the tree. Nodes and cursors will keep that structure internally, and contribute to that reference count. 

On every access, we check whether the tree has changed, and throw an error if it did.

This should perform better, and may be more desirable in some cases (why would the code use a node from a modified tree? ~This never worked correctly before~ It did, maybe. Original unmodified and copied trees are the same tree. So it is technically legal to copy a tree, get nodes from the original, modify the original, and still expect the nodes to work)

I also haven't figured out why we must copy the trees for it to crash:
```lua
local trees = {}
for k, tree in pairs(parser:trees()) do
  trees[k] = tree:copy()
end

...

parser:parse(true)
trees = nil
```

Without copying, even if the entire structure of the new tree from `parse()` is completely different from that of the old tree (parts of the tree are also reference counted), all references to that old tree continue to work. As if there's a memory leak and old tree with all its nodes is not deallocated. But I didn't find a memory leak.

@vanaigr looks like tree-sitter's `ts_tree_delete` is deleting some data without first checking that the reference count is at zero. The following repro crashes Neovim for me, instantly:

```lua
local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(0, 'lua')
local tree = parser:parse()[1]
local tree_copy = tree:copy()
tree_copy:__gc()  -- Garbage collect (ts_tree_delete) the copied tree
vim.schedule(function()
  vim.cmd.normal('gcj')
end)
```

```
nvim minimal.lua --clean -u minimal.lua 
```

Reproduction for https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31758#issuecomment-2564564436

(does it run without nvim-treesitter? It doesn't for me)

<details>

minimal.lua:
```lua
for name, url in pairs {
  nvim_treesitter = 'https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter.git',
} do
  local install_path = vim.fn.fnamemodify('nvim_issue/' .. name, ':p')
  if vim.fn.isdirectory(install_path) == 0 then
    vim.fn.system { 'git', 'clone', '--depth=1', url, install_path }
  end
  vim.opt.runtimepath:append(install_path)
end

require'nvim-treesitter.configs'.setup {
  ensure_installed = { "lua" },
}

local line = 'vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(0, { 1, 0 });'
local lines = {}
for i = 1, 2000 do lines[i] = line end
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, lines)

local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(0, 'lua')
local tree = parser:parse()[1]
local tree_copy = tree:copy()
tree_copy:__gc()  -- Garbage collect (ts_tree_delete) the copied tree
vim.schedule(function()
  vim.cmd.normal('gcj')
end)
```

version:
```console
NVIM v0.11.0-dev-1423+g48c09ed4d9
Build type: Debug
LuaJIT 2.1.1734355927
```

run:
```shell
nvim --clean -u minimal.lua
```

Stacktrace:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/06a8ec0a-37de-445f-8771-bdc99e122ffa)

</details>

> (does it run without nvim-treesitter? It doesn't for me)

If you happen to be using arch, they don't bundle the lua parser even though it is bundled typically (shipped from core anyway). So on arch it's too minimalistic and needs nvim-treesitter. Other distros maybe do the same. For me it works without `nvim-treesitter`, and even on small files (<10 lines)

Is it legal to call `__gc()`? Looks like it double frees.
I guess when the script finishes execution, all unreferenced local variables are garbage collected. It doesn't crash if the tree copy is stored in `_G`.

<details>

```console
(gdb) print &copy->included_range_count
$2 = (unsigned int *) 0x555555cac718
(gdb) watch *(unsigned int *) 0x555555cac718
Hardware watchpoint 3: *(unsigned int *) 0x555555cac718
(gdb) break tree_gc
Breakpoint 4 at 0x26109b: tree_gc. (2 locations)
```
(The address of the tree is `0x555555cac700`)
Then it is freed the first time:

```console
(gdb) continue
Continuing.

Thread 2.1 "nvim" hit Breakpoint 4, tree_gc (L=0x7ffff7bfa380) at /home/vanaigr/neovim2/src/nvim/lua/treesitter.c:790
790       TSLuaTree *ud = luaL_checkudata(L, 1, TS_META_TREE);
(gdb) next
791       ts_tree_delete(ud->tree);
(gdb) print *ud->tree
$3 = {root = {data = {is_inline = false, visible = false, named = false, extra = false, has_changes = false, is_missing = true,
      is_keyword = false, symbol = 110 'n', parse_state = 21964, padding_columns = 85 'U', padding_rows = 5 '\005',
      lookahead_bytes = 5 '\005', padding_bytes = 0 '\000', size_bytes = 0 '\000'}, ptr = 0x555555cc6ea0},
  language = 0x7ffff7ab8d20 <language>, included_ranges = 0x555555cb3510, included_range_count = 1}
(gdb) print ud->tree
$4 = (TSTree *) 0x555555cac700
```

Then we see the memory getting reused:

```console
(gdb) continue
Continuing.

Thread 2.1 "nvim" hit Hardware watchpoint 3: *(unsigned int *) 0x555555cac718

Old value = 1
New value = 1835627630
__memmove_avx_unaligned_erms () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memmove-vec-unaligned-erms.S:399
399     ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memmove-vec-unaligned-erms.S: No such file or directory.
(gdb) continue
Continuing.

Thread 2.1 "nvim" hit Hardware watchpoint 3: *(unsigned int *) 0x555555cac718

Old value = 1835627630
New value = 1768316772
__memmove_avx_unaligned_erms () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memmove-vec-unaligned-erms.S:397
397     in ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memmove-vec-unaligned-erms.S
```

Then it is freed again:

```console
(gdb) continue
Continuing.

Thread 2.1 "nvim" hit Breakpoint 4, tree_gc (L=0x7ffff7bfa380) at /home/vanaigr/neovim2/src/nvim/lua/treesitter.c:790
790       TSLuaTree *ud = luaL_checkudata(L, 1, TS_META_TREE);
(gdb) next
791       ts_tree_delete(ud->tree);
(gdb) print ud->tree
$5 = (TSTree *) 0x555555cac700
(gdb) continue
Continuing.
```

And then it crashes:

```console
Thread 2.1 "nvim" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
                                                              0x00007ffff7d273fe in __GI___libc_free (mem=0x616f6c5f64696410) at ./malloc/malloc.c:3368
3368    ./malloc/malloc.c: No such file or directory.

```

</details>

> If you happen to be using arch, they don't bundle the lua parser even though it is bundled typically (shipped from core anyway). So on arch it's too minimalistic and needs nvim-treesitter.

This means the arch build is _broken_, and you should complain to them. The (lua, vimdoc, markdown) parsers are a **mandatory** part of Nvim's runtime.

labels.description: issue reporting a crash or segfault
labels.name: bug-crash

title: Crash when using old `TSNode` after reparse
